qas.question: What did Feynman's discoveries hurt the explanation of?
Which parts of the Yang-Mills theories did Feynman dispel?

context: After the success of <a0_0><b5_0>quantum electrodynamics<b5_0/><a0_0/>, Feynman turned to quantum gravity. By analogy with the photon, which has spin 1, he investigated the <a1_0><b6_0>consequences of a free massless spin 2 field<b6_0/><a1_0/>, and derived the <a2_0><b7_0>Einstein field equation of general relativity<b7_0/><a2_0/>, but little more. The computational device that Feynman discovered then for gravity, "ghosts", which are "particles" in the interior of his diagrams that have the "wrong" connection between spin and statistics, have proved invaluable in explaining the quantum particle behavior of the <a3_0><b8_0>Yang–Mills theories<b8_0/><a3_0/>, for example, <a4_0><b9_0>QCD and the electro-weak theory<b9_0/><a4_0/>.
